Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Divn Of Social and Economic Sciences

Award.AbstractNarration:
Title: Examining Case Outcomes in Housing Court

Abstract

Eviction can have devastating economic, psychological, and social consequences for tenants. Yet, many tenants facing eviction choose not to attend their hearing in Housing Court, resulting in automatic loss of their case and a much greater likelihood of being evicted. This occurs in part because many tenants are unaware of their judicial options. This project will study whether providing tenants facing eviction with timely informational reminders can overcome the barriers that keep tenants from attending their hearing.

This study will explore the role of information in the judicial process of eviction, a context in which the problems of informational asymmetry and litigant confusion about tenants' legal rights are particularly pronounced. To do so, this project will measure the influence of time pressures and information on tenants facing eviction in Housing Court, by providing randomly assigned tenants facing eviction with a self-help mailer that links to a website containing accessible, actionable information. Case outcomes of those in the treatment group receiving the information will be compared against those of the control group. In this mixed methods study, quantitative data will be collected and qualitative interviews will be conducted. Outcomes examined will include whether tenants in the treatment group are more likely to show up to hearings, to file an answer-type document, and to settle before trial, and whether tenants in the treatment group are less likely to be evicted and to have a subsequent eviction action filed against them.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This study was designed to better understand how tenants in Arizona experience the judicial process of summary eviction and whether that experience might be meaningfully improved by self-help. First, we worked with local courts and legal aid organizations for three years to co-design self-help materials that we hypothesized might improve court attendance and case participation. Second, we randomized the receipt of these self-help materials to over four thousand tenants facing eviction in Pima County Justice Court from January to May 2019. After the eviction hearings, we analyzed whether treated tenants were more likely to attend court, have their case dismissed, or owe their landlord less money. Third, we conducted over 100 post-hearing surveys and over 20 hour-long qualitative interviews to better understand how past justice experiences impacted tenants' experiences of their eviction hearing and whether their eviction impacted their experience of the civil justice system.

We found no evidence that our self-help improved court attendance or case outcomes; in contrast, treated tenants were significantly more likely to owe their landlords more money. In addition, our analysis of heterogenous treatment effects provides suggestive evidence that self-help negatively impacts tenants whose landlords are business entities and tenants who live in block-groups with high concentrations of renters. Our qualitative results demonstrated that tenants attended court for three primary reasons: 1) to seek information or achieve an improved outcome; 2) to dispute the landlord’s accusations; and, 3) to perform—and defend—their own narrative of good citizenship. 

Our randomized study results suggest that self-help, although currently a best-practice, is unlikely to play a major role in improving court attendance or case outcomes for most tenants. Our qualitative results, however, may inform future interventions that might fare better. By understanding the justice perceptions that tenants bring with them to court, and the reasons tenants give for attendance, courts can provide for a better customer experience which may improve confidence in the judiciary. Unfortunately, Arizona housing court is currently ill-designed to meet the goals that tenants verbalized in our interviews. Tenants often leave confused and unable to challenge their landlord or control their narrative. We conclude by re-imagining housing court as a solution space designed to address each of these attendance goals in order to re-inspire confidence that the justice system also belongs to tenants.
